newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel ministry plans new West Bank settlement.
newsitem.headline: Israel ministry plans new West Bank settlement.

text.p: Israel's Housing Ministry is planning a new settlement for ultra-Orthodox Jews in the West Bank, a ministry spokeswoman said on Monday.
The planning is going on despite the government having yet to decide to approve the building of a new settlement.
"It is correct that a new settlement is being planned for Nachliel," a ministry spokeswoman said when asked to confirm media reports.
She said the plans called for state-funded construction of some 2,000 new housing units near Palestinian-ruled Ramallah in the West Bank, captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war.
"This is only at the very early planning stages and will have to pass through many offices before...approval," she said.

An aide to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel's right-wing government, which overturned a four-year freeze on building settlements in occupied Arab territories after taking power in June, had not ruled out building new settlements.

"It has not decided either for or against new settlements but it has established the right of Jews to live in Judea and Samaria," Netanyahu's communications director David Bar-Illan told Reuters, using biblical names for the West Bank.
The building of a new settlement in the occupied lands must be approved by the government. Approval of expansion of existing settlements rests with Defence Minister Yitzhak Mordechai.

"The decision of the two ministers is not a government decision. It is an announcement of intent. It is not even a government proposal yet," Bar-Illan added. Infrastructure Minister Ariel Sharon backs the housing ministry plans.

Some 130,000 Jews have settled amongst the nearly two million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Palestinians view the settlers as a provocation and vehemently oppose any expansion of Jewish settlements in territories where they hope to build an independent state.

Netanyahu's settlement policy has thus far been limited to expansion of existing settlements. Jewish settlers have said they are in fact upset at Netanyahu for what they call the "continued freeze" of settlement construction.
"On Wednesday we will launch a three-day protest outside the prime minister's office," a spokeswoman for the Yesha Council, the settlers' umbrella group, told Reuters.
